title: Fix DevlogDetails sticky headings hierarchy structure
description: Fix the hierarchical structure of headings in DevlogDetails component so that sticky headings work properly. Currently all sections (Description, Business Context, Technical Context, etc.) use `Title level={4}` creating flat h4 elements. Need to restructure them with proper heading hierarchy (h2 for main sections, h3 for subsections) so the existing StickyHeadings component can display meaningful hierarchical context when scrolling.

notes.content:
ðŸŽ¯ **REFACTORED DevlogDetails to use simple CSS sticky positioning!** Replaced the complex StickyHeadings component with natural CSS `position: sticky` for section headers.

**Key Changes:**
1. **DevlogDetails.tsx**: Wrapped all section titles in `.sectionHeader` divs
2. **DevlogDetails.module.css**: Added CSS sticky positioning with `top: 120px` to account for the devlog header
3. **DevlogDetailsPage.tsx**: Removed StickyHeadingsWrapper component usage
4. **Visual styling**: Added backdrop blur, subtle borders, and hover effects for a modern look

**Benefits:**
- Much simpler, more natural behavior like VS Code
- No complex JavaScript intersection observers
- Lightweight CSS-only solution
- Headers stick naturally when scrolled past and disappear when section ends
- Clean visual integration with existing design

context.businessContext: The sticky headings feature is already implemented and working, but the DevlogDetails component doesn't provide meaningful navigation context because all sections are at the same heading level. Users expect to see hierarchical breadcrumbs when scrolling through long devlog content, similar to VS Code/JetBrains IDEs.
context.technicalContext: Replace the complex StickyHeadings component approach with simple CSS `position: sticky` for DevlogDetails section headings. This will provide a more natural, VS Code-like experience where section headings (Description, Business Context, Technical Context, etc.) stick to the top when scrolling past them. The current StickyHeadings component is overly complex and relies on HTML tag detection rather than natural CSS sticky positioning.
acceptanceCriteria: Section headings stick to top when scrolled past using CSS position sticky
Natural scrolling behavior similar to VS Code
No complex JavaScript intersection observers needed
Visual design remains clean and uncluttered
Headings disappear naturally when their section is no longer visible
Works smoothly with the existing devlog header that's already sticky
